There are a couple of other considerations in choosing an activation 
metho=
d that I don't think have been discussed that are at least worth 
mentionin=
g.  Like I said, there are pros and cons both ways so 
there's no knockdown=
 argument one way or another, just things to 
consider:

-The order-indepen=
dent method of activation can utilize a kind 
of "delay chain memory" while=
 in-order activation cannot.  A delay 
chain is a long chain of nodes that =
prevents activation from arriving 
from the inputs at the outputs until a f=
ew timesteps (equal to the 
length of the chain) in the future.  Some trans=
formations may happen 
along the way as well.  But what it means is that th=
e network can 
react to past events even without recurrent connections.  Th=
is kind 
of "memory" is less sophisticated than recurrent memory, but it 
a=
ctually can work.  I forget who it was, but a couple years ago 
someone sen=
t me an example where they forgot to enable recurrence in 
NEAT, and still =
solved a problem that was supposed to be impossible 
without it.  The solut=
ion networks were full of long chains of nodes.

-A big advantage of order-=
independent activation is that you don't 
need to know which connections ar=
e recurrent and which are not in 
order to activate properly.  In fact, you=
 treat all connections 
exactly the same: every connection moves activation=
 from its source 
at time t to its destination at t+1.  Thus there is no ne=
ed to 
distinguish.  NEAT tries to distinguish mostly just for the user's 
=
conceptual convenience, but the reason NEAT is able to do that is 
that con=
nections are added one at a time so it can check for each new 
connection w=
hether it introduces a loop.  But in practice if I gave 
you a giant random=
 mesh of nodes (i.e. a brain), figuring out which 
connections are recurren=
t is not trivial.  With order-independent 
activation it doesn't matter and=
 everything will work right 
automatically.
